Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: New Reactivity Promoted by Group 5 Metal Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, the research groups of Professors John Arnold and Robert Bergman of University of California, Berkeley are working toward developing new reagents containing inexpensive and earth-abundant early transition metals that are capable of cleaving strong bonds. Ideally, this research will lead to development of catalysts for removal of fluorine and chlorine from environmentally dangerous halogenated organic wastes, such as CFCs, selective functionalization of chemical feedstocks to produce high-valued organic products, and synthesis of new inorganic polymers and materials. The most immediate broader impacts of the work described in this proposal relate to the training of skilled synthetic chemists and the fact that a more complete understanding of fundamental reaction steps that occur at transition metal sites is important in a wide range of industrially important chemical conversions.

This project focuses on the development of new niobium systems supported by imido and β-diketiminate and related ligands. This project is split into two major parts. The first involves reactivity and mechanistic studies of low-valent niobium systems toward developing reagents for activation and functionalization of C-F, C-Cl, and C-O bonds. The second involves synthesis of a series of bis(imido) complexes that are reactive across a niobium-nitrogen multiple bond, and investigation of their reactivity toward cycloaddition of unsaturated substrates and 1,2-addition of C-H and E-H (E = H, B, Al, Si, N, P, O, S) bonds. Target compounds will be characterized using 1D and 2D 1H, 13C, and other heteronuclear NMR techniques, X-ray crystallography, FT-IR (Fourier transform infra-red) spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, and other characterization techniques. Additionally, DFT (Density Functional Theory) calculations will be used to gain electronic structure and mechanistic insights.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Molecules containing transition metal (groups 3–12) centers are able to catalyze an astounding variety of chemical processes with far-reaching applications, from the synthesis of an increasingly diverse array of polymers to the reduction of vehicle emissions by catalytic converters. The transition metals can be separated into two categories based on the reaction pathways that complexes containing these metals tend to follow: the early and the late transition metals. The boundary line between these two groups runs vertically down the center of the d-block of the periodic table, with metals in groups 3–5 typically being labeled “early” and those in groups 8–12 referred to as “late.” The metals in groups 6 and 7 tend to fall between these two hard distinctions and are sometimes referred to as the “mid” transition metals. The late transition metals are able to exist in a wide variety of readily accessible oxidation states and easily undergo ligand dissociation/association processes; as such, complexes containing these metals are often found as catalysts, including in our bodies (examples include the binding and release of oxygen by iron in blood cells and the breaking of chemical bonds by cobalt during metabolism).

 

In stark contrast to their late-metal congeners, the early transition metals possess relatively high-energy valence d-orbitals; often, complexes containing these metals are found in d0 oxidation states with no valence electrons available to engage in redox chemistry. As such, these transition metal complexes tend form very strong bonds to ligands and engage in redox-neutral (no change in oxidation state) bond making and breaking processes, with σ-bond metathesis being the prime example. Because of these differences, the molecular chemistry of the early transition metals is underdeveloped relative to that of the late transition metals. Our research aims to challenge this paradigm by exploring new modes of reactivity that can be access using early transition metals. Our work in this arena can be separated into two strategies: 1) using metal-ligand multiple bond(s) to provide electrons for redox-reactivity in high-valent early transition metal complexes and 2) synthesizing reactive low-valent early metal centers that are able to carry out powerful reductions. In particular, our group focuses on the group 5 early transition metals, namely niobium and tantalum, as well as the mid transition metal rhenium.

 

In terms of intellectual merit, our research in this area has led to numerous (~20) publications in peer-reviewed journals, presentations and first place awards at scientific conferences, and three successful Ph.D. dissertations. Most notably, we were able to demonstrate and study the activation and, in some cases, cleavage and functionalization of dinitrogen, carbon monoxide, and dihydrogen at early transition metal centers; this body of work contributes valuable knowledge to the field of sustainable chemistry, which aims to reduce the environmental impact of chemical transformations of these abundant feedstock molecules. In carrying out the work laid out in this proposal, project members developed as skilled synthetic chemists who are well-informed on principles of sustainability, who can plan and carry out demanding synthetic schemes, and who have the ability to communicate the work they do in a manner that is understandable to a broad range of society. Given the importance of synthetic chemistry to the nation’s manufacturing industry and its contribution to the US GDP, the training of synthetic chemists is of vital importance to the nation’s health. In addition to the technical aspects of this proposal, students receiving funding also made broader impacts through teaching appointments for undergraduate and graduate courses, mentoring of undergraduate research assistants (with a particular focus on integrating transfer students from non-traditional backgrounds into our research group), and by organizing frequent science outreach lessons for local elementary school students. Students worked in conjunction with both the Bay Area Scientists in Schools (BASIS) program and Oakland Unified School District’s Keeping Students Engaged in Science (KSES) Collaborative to develop and implement frequent inquiry-based chemistry lessons for local elementary and middle school students that aim to engage younger students and educate them on basic chemical principles. These lessons promote broader scientific knowledge amongst younger students of all backgrounds while also encouraging curiosity and an inclination to pursue science as a career. Thus, with the assistance of our NSF support we have focused not only on the development of our own Ph.D. students, but on the development of the next generation of scientists as well.
